wikipedia_page.main: James Martin Child  (20 October 1893 – 23 August 1918) was a World War I flying ace. A British citizen living in Canada when the war began, he returned home for service. After being assigned to the Royal Flying Corps, he was credited with eight aerial victories. He died while rescuing a fellow pilot from a crashed aircraft.

response: * James Martin Child, World War I ace

link_mentions.page: List of World War I aces credited with 8 victories

response: On 4 January 1917, Lieutenant F. E. Brown was seconded for duty with the Royal Flying Corps as a Flying Officer, with seniority from 29 August 1916. Note: The imputation of the seniority date is that it denotes the beginning of Brown's stint with the RFC. On 17 May 1917, he was Mentioned in Despatches by Sir Douglas Haig. On 14 July 1917, he was awarded the French Croix de Guerre. On 8 November 1917, while posted to 84 Squadron as a SE.5a pilot, Brown scored his first aerial victory, driving down an Albatros D.V out of control east of Poelcapelle. The win was shared with James Martin Child.

response: *Lt. James Martin Child, Manchester Reg., and Royal Flying Corps
